much better. it is tough and at times it takes us a whole month without getting any piecework. we need piece jobs because we have to eat. we also have to pay rent when month ends, <q> he says. he avoids eye contact with me, focusing instead on his construction safety boots, momentarily lowering his cap to cover his face further, his battered cell-phone also being a pad that he continuously plays with. but why does he not go back to the village if life in metropolitan gaborone is so unbearable? the answer lies in the tragedy of an accident of birth, one that ensures one does not choose the families they want to be born into. </q> life back home is far worse. here at least one can get some money from piece work. back home there is nothing at all, it's better to suffer here in the city.
